name: Cactus
climate: Cacti are typically found in arid and desert climates with minimal rainfall.
They can also adapt to semi-arid regions where water is more sporadic.
Some cacti species thrive in tropical areas offering wet and dry seasons.
A well-draining climate with temperatures not falling below freezing is ideal.
sunlight: Cacti require full sunlight to thrive and maintain their structural health.
In extremely hot and dry climates, slight shading may prevent sunburn.
Indoor cacti need bright sunlight, often near south or west-facing windows.
Too little sunlight can result in elongated growth and weaker stems.
watering: Cacti have low water needs due to their adaptation to desert environments.
Watering should be infrequent, allowing the soil to dry completely between sessions.
Overwatering can lead to root rot, a common issue in potted cacti.
During winter when growth is minimal, reduce watering significantly.
soil: Cacti require a fast-draining soil to mimic their natural habitats efficiently.
Soil should be gritty, often mixing sand or perlite for optimal drainage.
Commercial cactus mixes are often used, providing a balance of nutrients.
Avoid moisture-retentive soils as they hold water excessively, harming the plant.
toxic: Many cacti have spines that can cause skin irritation and injury upon contact.
Certain species of cacti can be mildly toxic if ingested, particularly to pets.
extra_care_tip: Rotate potted cacti periodically to ensure even growth and sun exposure.
Check for pests such as mealybugs and treat promptly to prevent damage.
Use a pot with drainage holes to avoid water stagnation at the roots.
Repot cacti in spring when they outgrow their current container.
